title: These 2-Ingredient Cuban Pastries Are "Buttery Perfection"
description: Golden, buttery, and bursting with tropical sweetness! READ MORE...
author: Patricia Suarez
excerpt: Golden, buttery, and bursting with tropical sweetness!
text: RecipesBreadsPastries & Sweet BunsGuava PastelitosPatricia SuarezPatricia Ysabella Suarez is a Miami-born chef with a culinary journey grounded in her Cuban heritage. She began with pop-up dinners in New York City, showcasing the nostalgic flavors of her roots, and later developed recipes for America’s Test Kitchen book team. Now a freelance…read morepublished yesterdayCredit: Photo: Alex Lepe; Food Stylist: Kelli FosterYou only need two ingredients to make this buttery, flaky treat.Makes9Prep15 minutesCook22 minutesWe independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.Credit: Photo: Alex Lepe; Food Stylist: Kelli FosterButtery puff pastry, sweet and tangy guava paste, and granulated sugar come together to create the ultimate breakfast treat, dessert, and snack. Meet: guava pastelitos. Though simple in ingredients, they deliver a burst of flavor you’ll find yourself craving time and time again. Pastelitos are the quintessential Cuban treat — whether savory or sweet, they can be enjoyed at any time of day and pair perfectly with a cafecito (Cuban coffee). Compared with sweet empanadas, pastelitos are made with a puff pastry, giving them a flakier, crispier finish. While guava itself has a delicate sweetness and mild floral notes, the paste concentrates those flavors, creating a bold, tangy-sweet filling. When tucked between buttery, flaky pastry layers, the contrast is irresistibly delicious. In this recipe, texture is just as important as taste. What makes a perfect pastelito stand out is its golden, flaky layers and sweet, shiny finish on top. Many puff recipes call for a 400°F oven temperature, but by lowering it to 375°F, you can cook the pastelitos for longer, guaranteeing that each buttery layer is cooked from within, without burning the exterior. Credit: Photo: Alex Lepe; Food Stylist: Kelli FosterWhy You’ll Love It Delicious in any shape and size. I try to aim for evenly cut puff pastry squares, but don’t stress over perfection. It’s delicious any way. Cooked to perfection. Baking the puff pastries at 375°F creates a beautifully golden crust on the exterior and ensures every layer inside bakes evenly.  Key Ingredients in Guava Pastelitos Puff pastry: There would be no recipe without the star ingredient’s buttery, flaky, and golden layers.  Guava paste: A sweet and tangy filling that adds a burst of tropical flavor. Guava paste is readily available in Latin grocery stores or often found in the “international aisle” or baking aisle in major grocery stores. Keep in mind that guava preserves will not give you the same results as guava paste.  Sugar (optional): A simple glaze made with just granulated sugar and hot water adds the perfect touch of sweetness, completing this classic treat.  Credit: Photo: Alex Lepe; Food Stylist: Kelli FosterHow to Make Guava Pastelitos  Prepare the puff pastry. Cut each sheet into 9 squares. Arrange half of the squares on a baking sheet, leaving space between them.  Assemble the pastelitos. Add guava paste to the center of each square, brushing edges with egg wash. Place a reserved square on top and seal. Glaze the pastries. If desired, brush the sugar glaze over the pastelitos immediately after baking. Helpful Swaps Melting guava paste creates a smooth, spreadable yet thick, consistency for more even distribution throughout the pastry. While not essential, this step can elevate the recipe. To do this, cut a 11-ounce block of guava paste into eight pieces and microwave it in intervals — start with 1 minute, stir, then continue in 30-second increments — until smooth. Scoop a heaping tablespoon onto each square and spread it evenly, leaving a 1/4-inch border. For easier scooping, spray the tablespoon with cooking spray.Storage and Make Ahead Tips Leftovers can be kept in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Reheat in a 350°F oven for 2 to 3 minutes.CommentsYou only need two ingredients to make this buttery, flaky treat.Nutritional InfoIngredients1 (14- to 17.5-ounce) package frozen puff pastry (preferably Pepperidge Farm), thawed but still cold1 large egg11 ounces guava paste, cut into 18 pieces2 tablespoons granulated sugar (optional)2 tablespoons hot water (optional)Heat the oven to 375°F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Beat 1 large egg in a small bowl.If using puff pastry that comes in 2 sheets, place 1 of the sheets on a cutting board. Roll out if needed into a 9-inch square. Cut into 9 (3-inch) squares. Transfer the squares to the baking sheet, spacing them evenly apart. Repeat cutting the second puff pastry sheet into 9 squares. (If using puff pastry that only comes in 1 sheet, roll out into a 9x18-inch rectangle, then cut into 18 (3-inch) squares. Transfer 9 to the baking sheet.)Place 2 pieces of the guava paste next to each other on the center of each square on the baking sheet. Brush the edges of each square with the egg wash. Top each one with a second puff pastry square. Gently press the edges together with a fork to seal.Brush the tops and edges of the pastries with the beaten egg. Use a small paring knife to cut a 2-inch diagonal slit through the top of each pastry.Bake for 15 minutes. Rotate the baking sheet. Bake until the pastries are puffed and golden brown, 10 to 15 minutes more. Meanwhile, if you’d like to glaze the pastries, stir 2 tablespoons granulated sugar and 2 tablespoons hot water together in a small bowl until the sugar dissolves.Remove the pastries from the oven. Brush the tops with the sugar glaze if using. Let cool for at least 10 minutes before serving.Recipe NotesGeneral tip: If the guava paste is too sticky while cutting, lightly spray the knife with cooking spray before cutting.Puff pastry: Look for puff pastry sheets in the freezer section. For best results, thaw in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours and up to 1 day before using.Storage: Leftovers can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 3 days. Reheat in a 300°F oven until warmed through, 3 to 5 minutes.
html:
• Recipes
  • Breads
  • Pastries & Sweet Buns

Guava Pastelitos

Patricia Suarez

Patricia Ysabella Suarez is a Miami-born chef with a culinary journey grounded in her Cuban heritage. She began with pop-up dinners in New York City, showcasing the nostalgic flavors of her roots, and later developed recipes for America’s Test Kitchen book team. Now a freelance…read more

published yesterday

You only need two ingredients to make this buttery, flaky treat.

Makes9

Prep15 minutes

Cook22 minutes

We independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.

Buttery puff pastry, sweet and tangy guava paste, and granulated sugar come together to create the ultimate breakfast treat, dessert, and snack. Meet: guava pastelitos. Though simple in ingredients, they deliver a burst of flavor you’ll find yourself craving time and time again. Pastelitos are the quintessential Cuban treat — whether savory or sweet, they can be enjoyed at any time of day and pair perfectly with a cafecito (Cuban coffee). Compared with sweet empanadas, pastelitos are made with a puff pastry, giving them a flakier, crispier finish. 

While guava itself has a delicate sweetness and mild floral notes, the paste concentrates those flavors, creating a bold, tangy-sweet filling. When tucked between buttery, flaky pastry layers, the contrast is irresistibly delicious. In this recipe, texture is just as important as taste. What makes a perfect pastelito stand out is its golden, flaky layers and sweet, shiny finish on top. Many puff recipes call for a 400°F oven temperature, but by lowering it to 375°F, you can cook the pastelitos for longer, guaranteeing that each buttery layer is cooked from within, without burning the exterior. 

Why You’ll Love It

  • Delicious in any shape and size. I try to aim for evenly cut puff pastry squares, but don’t stress over perfection. It’s delicious any way.
  • Cooked to perfection. Baking the puff pastries at 375°F creates a beautifully golden crust on the exterior and ensures every layer inside bakes evenly. 

Key Ingredients in Guava Pastelitos

  • Puff pastry: There would be no recipe without the star ingredient’s buttery, flaky, and golden layers. 
  • Guava paste: A sweet and tangy filling that adds a burst of tropical flavor. Guava paste is readily available in Latin grocery stores or often found in the “international aisle” or baking aisle in major grocery stores. Keep in mind that guava preserves will not give you the same results as guava paste. 
  • Sugar (optional): A simple glaze made with just granulated sugar and hot water adds the perfect touch of sweetness, completing this classic treat. 

How to Make Guava Pastelitos 

  1. Prepare the puff pastry. Cut each sheet into 9 squares. Arrange half of the squares on a baking sheet, leaving space between them. 
  2. Assemble the pastelitos. Add guava paste to the center of each square, brushing edges with egg wash. Place a reserved square on top and seal.
  3. Glaze the pastries. If desired, brush the sugar glaze over the pastelitos immediately after baking.

Helpful Swaps 

Melting guava paste creates a smooth, spreadable yet thick, consistency for more even distribution throughout the pastry. While not essential, this step can elevate the recipe. To do this, cut a 11-ounce block of guava paste into eight pieces and microwave it in intervals — start with 1 minute, stir, then continue in 30-second increments — until smooth. Scoop a heaping tablespoon onto each square and spread it evenly, leaving a 1/4-inch border. For easier scooping, spray the tablespoon with cooking spray.

Storage and Make Ahead Tips 

Leftovers can be kept in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Reheat in a 350°F oven for 2 to 3 minutes.

Comments

You only need two ingredients to make this buttery, flaky treat.

Nutritional Info

Ingredients

  • 1 (14- to 17.5-ounce) package

    frozen puff pastry (preferably Pepperidge Farm), thawed but still cold

  • 1

    large egg

  • 11 ounces

    guava paste, cut into 18 pieces

  • 2 tablespoons

    granulated sugar (optional)

  • 2 tablespoons

    hot water (optional)

  1. Heat the oven to 375°F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Beat 1 large egg in a small bowl.

  2. If using puff pastry that comes in 2 sheets, place 1 of the sheets on a cutting board. Roll out if needed into a 9-inch square. Cut into 9 (3-inch) squares. Transfer the squares to the baking sheet, spacing them evenly apart. Repeat cutting the second puff pastry sheet into 9 squares. (If using puff pastry that only comes in 1 sheet, roll out into a 9x18-inch rectangle, then cut into 18 (3-inch) squares. Transfer 9 to the baking sheet.)

  3. Place 2 pieces of the guava paste next to each other on the center of each square on the baking sheet. Brush the edges of each square with the egg wash. Top each one with a second puff pastry square. Gently press the edges together with a fork to seal.

  4. Brush the tops and edges of the pastries with the beaten egg. Use a small paring knife to cut a 2-inch diagonal slit through the top of each pastry.

  5. Bake for 15 minutes. Rotate the baking sheet. Bake until the pastries are puffed and golden brown, 10 to 15 minutes more. Meanwhile, if you’d like to glaze the pastries, stir 2 tablespoons granulated sugar and 2 tablespoons hot water together in a small bowl until the sugar dissolves.

  6. Remove the pastries from the oven. Brush the tops with the sugar glaze if using. Let cool for at least 10 minutes before serving.

Recipe Notes

General tip: If the guava paste is too sticky while cutting, lightly spray the knife with cooking spray before cutting.

Puff pastry: Look for puff pastry sheets in the freezer section. For best results, thaw in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours and up to 1 day before using.

Storage: Leftovers can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 3 days. Reheat in a 300°F oven until warmed through, 3 to 5 minutes.
